text.p: The following is a direct contribution from commodity statistician F.O. Licht in Ratzeburg, Germany. Please address any queries to Helmut Ahlfeld on +00 49 4541 88920.
White sugar futures in London closed marginally higher across the board. Front month August finished at $321.90, up $0.70, while October added $0.90 to close at $315.60 per tonne.

Raw sugar futures in New York ended a thinly traded session higher with front month October adding 3 points to close at 11.09 cents/lb. March closed at 11.25 cents/lb, up 1 point. Prices could come under pressure on Monday following Brazil's decision to practically free sugar exports. Even though that will not materially affect the supply and demand balance, the decision could have a psychological impact.

BRAZIL - After Brazil's Industry and Commerce Ministry increased export quotas for 1997/98 by 1.67 million tonnes, tel quel, the Central Bank the same day released a circular reducing the tax on all exports of sugar and derivatives to zero which effectively makes the quota increase irrelevant. Sugar exports traditionally have been governed by quotas set out in the government crop plan issued at the beginning of the season and which are allocated by individual factory.

These quotas can be exported tax-free, otherwise they are liable to a 40 per cent export tax. Any additional quotas have to be negotiated with the government although in the past this has proved to be a lengthy process. The other key issue is the fact that the export tax is still being retained, albeit at zero. This still gives the government the power to increase the tax if it believes that internal sugar and alcohol supply is being compromised.

UKRAINE - Sugar exports in May 1997 reached 91,185 tonnes, raw value, down from 122,294 tonnes exported in April 1997. This brought cumulative exports in the first five months of 1997 (January/May) up to 463,588 tonnes. Major countries of destination in 1997 were Russia with 313,899 tonnes whites, Belarus with 32,900 tonnes, Turkmenistan with 16,600 tonnes and Azerbaijan with 15,000 tonnes.

DENMARK - Sugar imports in April 1997 amounted to 10,177 tonnes, raw value, up from 2,148 tonnes imported in April 1996. This brought cumulative imports in the first ten months of 1996/97 (October/April) up to 89,801 tonnes compared to 5,916 tonnes in 1995/96. Total imports in 1995/96 reached 29,387 tonnes against 4,960 tonnes in 1994/95. Major countries of origin in 1996/97 were Germany with 13,704 tonnes whites against 4,846 tonnes and Sweden with 11,855 tonnes, up from 78 tonnes.

Sugar exports in April 1997 amounted to 32,785 tonnes, sharply up on 12,890 tonnes exported in April 1996. This brought cumulative exports in October/April 1996/97 up to 111,139 tonnes against 95,339 tonnes in 1995/96. Total exports in 1995/96 reached 173,004 tonnes against 199,559 tonnes in 1994/95. Major countries of destination in 1996/97 were Norway with 52,345 tonnes whites against 67,500 tonnes and Libya with 30,800 tonnes compared to nil.

TURKEY - Sugar imports in September 1996 reached 66,397 tonnes, raw value, down from 99,621 tonnes in September 1995. This brought cumulative imports in the first two months of 1996/97 (August/September) up to 197,566 tonnes, down from 220,054 tonnes in 1995/96. Total imports in 1995/96 amounted to 905,553 tonnes compared to 191,885 tonnes in 1994/95.

Major countries of origin in 1996/97 were Mexico with 96,403 tonnes whites against nil, France with 66,951 tonnes, down from 91,046 tonnes and Austria with 4,400 tonnes against 642 tonnes. Sugar exports in 1996/97 were negligible.
